persona.name: Tamsin Reid

occupation.title: Senior Project Manager / Delivery Lead
occupation.organization: Mid-sized technology consultancy (specialist in enterprise healthcare systems)
occupation.description: Tamsin is an experienced delivery lead responsible for planning and executing multiple concurrent software implementation projects for NHS trusts and private hospitals. Their responsibilities include scoping requirements with clinical and administrative stakeholders, producing project plans and budgets, coordinating cross-functional teams (developers, clinical leads, integration engineers, vendors), managing risks, ensuring compliance with data protection laws (GDPR), and leading post-live stabilisation and benefits realisation. They act as the primary client-facing contact during delivery, run weekly steering committees, lead change management activities, and coach junior PMs. Tamsin is comfortable in both waterfall and Agile frameworks, frequently balancing regulatory requirements and procurement constraints with iterative delivery. They sometimes spend two to three days per week on client sites and the rest remote. Typical challenges include negotiating scope with risk-averse clinicians, adapting timelines to procurement cycles, and aligning vendors' roadmaps with client needs. Relevant expertise: stakeholder mapping, clinical workflows, enterprise rollouts, contract interpretation, cloud migration basics, vendor management, benefits tracking.

persona.education: MSc Engineering Management, University of Manchester. Bachelor's in Computer Science, University of Edinburgh. Additional professional certifications: PRINCE2 Practitioner, Certified Scrum Product Owner (CSPO), GDPR Foundation.
long_term_goals: Lead a mid-sized consultancy practice focused on improving healthcare delivery with pragmatic technology solutions.
Buy and renovate a modest three-bedroom terraced house with a dedicated home office and a small courtyard garden.
Develop mentoring programs for early-career technologists from underrepresented backgrounds.
Achieve financial independence so work becomes a choice rather than a necessity by age 50.
Maintain a sustainable life balance: regular travel, healthy body, meaningful relationships, and occasional creative projects.
Publish a practical guide for clinicians and managers on how to run digital transformation projects in hospitals.
persona.style: Direct, pragmatic and slightly wry. Speaks with a London urban accent, relatively neutral but with occasional Estuary English vowels; uses they/them pronouns and flips to colloquial phrasing in informal settings. In meetings they are concise, use bullet-pointed language, and like to name actions/ppl with deadlines. When under pressure they shortens sentences and adds dry humor to ease tension. Mannerisms include: tapping the side of their laptop when thinking, folding hands into a tent when negotiating, pausing deliberately before asking questions to create space for quieter stakeholders, and a private nervous habit of fiddling with the band of their watch. They prefer clear agendas and annotated slides rather than long monologues. When relaxed with friends they speak faster and laugh loudly; with senior stakeholders they slow down and use precise terminology. They occasionally pepper speech with mild profanity for emphasis. Email style is polite but economical: clear subject lines, action-oriented bullet lists, and a 'decisions' section at the top. Social media presence is restrained; LinkedIn used professionally, Instagram for photos of travel and food. They choose gender-neutral clothing that prioritises comfort and a clean cut—jeans, smart trainers, unstructured blazers—and tend to present as intentionally low-fuss but neat.

traits: Strategic thinker who likes to map outcomes and consequences before committing.
Pragmatic and results-oriented; prefers solving problems rather than debating them endlessly.
Empathetic listener—makes room for quieter voices in meetings and remembers personal details about colleagues.
Slightly skeptical of buzzwords and hype; asks for evidence and pilot results.
Has a dry, self-deprecating sense of humor; uses humor to defuse stress.
Prefers predictable routines but can adapt quickly when circumstances demand it.
Perfectionist about deliverables but willing to accept 'good enough' for early iterations.
Resilient under stress; recovers from setbacks by creating a new plan.
Values fairness and transparency; gets frustrated by opaque decision-making.
Can be guarded about personal matters; shares selectively until trust is built.
Mentoring-oriented: invests time in developing direct reports.
Occasionally prone to overworking in busy periods and then requiring deliberate downtime.

Project management practices and process improvement.
Urban gardening—container plants, herbs and a small citrus tree on the balcony.
Independent coffee shops with stable Wi-Fi for focused afternoon work.
Non-fiction books about technology policy and organisational change.
Contemporary British and indie music; small venue gigs.
Weekend short-trips and city breaks in Europe.
Board games with strategic depth (e.g., Pandemic Legacy, Terraforming Mars).
Podcast listening—long-form interviews and investigative journalism.
Cooking seasonal recipes and experimenting with spices from markets.
Photography—phone photography focused on candid street scenes.
Podcast production basics; interested in starting a short series about tech in healthcare.
Cycling short commutes when weather permits.
Minimalist home aesthetics balanced with a few sentimental objects.
Documentaries about science, public policy, and architecture.
Language learning—intermediate Spanish.
Practices for improving concentration (time-blocking, Pomodoro).
Ethical consumerism—prefers durable goods over fast-fashion.
Volunteering occasionally with a charity that supports digital literacy for seniors.
Learning about negotiated procurement and public-sector contracting.

Environmental activism
Public policy
Cooperatives and alternative economic systems

Political theory favoring order and structure

Mid-week curry nights with friends and good conversation.
Travel itineraries that balance 'one main thing per day' with downtime.
Open-plan but quiet co-working spaces with booths for calls.
Notes that are action-oriented and have a clear owner and deadline.
Comfortable shoes that still look presentable in meetings.
Multipurpose gadgets that reduce clutter—wireless earbuds with good battery life.
Simple but good-quality kitchen knives and a cast-iron pan.
Small honest product labels and transparent supply chains.

Walking home through a city at dusk.
Books that blend personal stories with practical advice.

A tidy inbox at the end of the day.
Seasonal fruit from independent greengrocers.
Sustainable packaging for delivered items.
Short, well-curated training sessions rather than long seminars.
A playlist that builds energy for focused work sessions.
Clear, simple dashboards that show real progress.
Receiving a short, handwritten thank-you note.
Public transportation and urban planning that prioritizes accessibility
Community-led initiatives and grassroots movements
Fair trade products and ethical consumption
Artists and movements that challenge the status quo

Well-maintained and orderly environments

Long meetings without an agenda or defined outcomes.
Unnecessary corporate jargon and meaningless KPIs.
Cold, soggy sandwiches at events.
Poorly configured collaboration tools that create email noise.
People who repeatedly miss agreed deadlines without communication.
Overly enthusiastic, inflexible sales pitches for one-size-fits-all solutions.
Excessive workplace politics and opaque promotion processes.
Crowded touristy areas with loud group tours.
Services that make it hard to access human support when needed.
Wasteful single-use plastics and unnecessary packaging.
Mediation-averse colleagues who avoid conflict until it explodes.
Being forced into morning meetings that clash with peak productivity.

Cheesy corporate-speak used to hide weak decisions.

Environmental degradation for profit

favorite_drinks: Occasional IPA from a local microbrewery
Strong black tea with a splash of milk
Ginger and lemon hot water when feeling rundown
Glasses of Rioja on special occasions
favorite_foods: Simple roast chicken with lemon and herbs
Fresh sourdough toast with ripe avocado and chilli flakes
snacks: Plain Greek yogurt with honey and granola
dietary_preferences: Not vegetarian but eats predominantly plant-forward meals during the week
Chooses dairy alternatives regularly (oatly, almond milk)
Prefers to cook from scratch when time allows

favorite_podcasts: A few narrative investigative journalism shows
streaming_and_shows: Occasional character-driven dramas and British comedies
apps_and_tools: Uses Notion for personal notes and project templates
Slack for work communication (keeps notifications curated)

beliefs: Public services should be designed around users, not internal hierarchies.
Technology is an amplifier: it makes existing intentions scale, so intent matters more than tools.
Clinicians should be involved from day one in any healthcare IT project.
Good project management reduces wasted money and avoids clinician burnout.
Data protection and patient privacy are non-negotiable priorities in healthcare.
Procurement cycles in the public sector need to be navigable but should still protect public interest.
Iterative pilots produce better long-term outcomes than big-bang rollouts in complex organisations.
Transparency in contracts and outcomes builds trust between vendors and public clients.
Diversity in project teams leads to better decision-making and more robust solutions.
Mentoring and access to networks are significant levers for career mobility.
Work-life balance requires active management, not passive hope.
Financial prudence and occasional risk-taking should coexist in a career strategy.
People tend to overestimate short-term costs and underestimate long-term benefits.
Climate considerations should influence procurement and office choices.
Urban environments should be planned to prioritise human comfort and accessible amenities.
Lifelong learning is essential—technology changes too fast to stay still.
Fair pay and clear progression paths are essential to retain talent in consultancy.
Public-sector transformation succeeds when leadership commits to change beyond a single term.
Small acts of kindness at work compound into better team resilience.
Being precise about responsibilities reduces stress and increases trust.
Mental health support in the workplace prevents chronic presenteeism.
People rarely change deeply held habits without clear motives and easy alternatives.
Open-source tools have a place in public-sector tech when sustainability and support are addressed.
Remote work increases inclusivity for some but can exacerbate isolation for others without deliberate design.
Personal integrity matters more than short-term career wins.
Investment in good onboarding has a high ROI for complex projects.
Being an ally requires action, not just good intentions.
Community-level volunteering improves perspective and reduces burnout.
Quality of life is correlated with predictable routines and meaningful downtime.
Decisions that centre dignity and autonomy produce better patient outcomes.
Economic systems should prioritize equality and fairness.
Healthcare and education are fundamental human rights.
The government has a responsibility to protect the environment and public well-being.
Workers should have a stronger voice in decision-making processes.
Wealth should be distributed more equitably to reduce poverty and inequality.
Community and cooperation are more effective than competition in creating progress.
Immigration enriches society and should be welcomed with fair policies.
Authority and order are essential for a functioning society.
Tradition provides a foundation for stability and continuity.
Discipline and structure foster personal and collective success.
Rules exist to guide and protect, and breaking them undermines progress.
Strong leadership is necessary to avoid anarchy and inefficiency.
skills: Project planning and complex programme coordination across multiple stakeholder groups.
Clinical workflow mapping and translating clinician needs into technical requirements.
Risk management and mitigation planning for regulated environments.
Budgeting and financial tracking for multi-phase implementations.
Agile practices and hybrid delivery (Scrum for development teams, PRINCE2-style reporting for governance).
Requirements elicitation and facilitation of workshops with clinicians, operations and procurement.
Stakeholder engagement and negotiation with senior leadership and unions.
Vendor management and contract interpretation with an eye for compliance.
Change management: communications planning, training rollouts, adoption tracking.
Basic SQL for ad-hoc data checks and comfort interpreting metrics and dashboards.
Data protection literacy: practical understanding of GDPR implications for project design.
Public speaking and steering committee chairing; able to present complex topics clearly.
Mentoring and line management for junior PMs and business analysts.
Time-blocking and productivity techniques to manage high workload periods.
Conflict resolution between technical teams and operational users.

general: Always sends a short 'decisions and actions' email after key meetings, even if they delegate the note-taking.
Reads long documents in two passes: skim for structure, then deep-dive into sections that affect delivery.
Brings a small notebook to client workshops, writes names and personal notes, then adds them to contacts.
Prefers to set 25–40 minute focused work blocks with short breaks (Pomodoro-like).
Will step out of meetings for a five-minute walk when stressed to clear their head.
Is proactive about asking quieter stakeholders for their input during meetings.
Uses checklists for project go-lives and post-live reviews.
Calms teams by breaking big tasks into clearly assigned next steps.
Prefers asynchronous updates where possible to reduce meeting load.
When fogged by a problem, draws a quick flowchart on a whiteboard to visualise options.
Participates in protests and community meetings.
Volunteers for local charities and organizations.
Frequently shares articles and opinions on social issues.
Avoids products and brands with poor ethical practices.
Challenges authority or norms when they seem unjust.
Criticizes people who do not follow rules or protocols.
Organizes belongings and workspace meticulously to reflect control.
Shows visible discomfort in unstructured or informal settings.
Frequently invokes traditional practices or authority to justify decisions.

morning: Wakes around 7:00 AM on workdays; quick stretching routine and a strong cup of coffee.
Scans email for urgent items, checks calendar blocks for the day, and reviews a short 10-minute 'top three' priorities list.
Cycling or walking to a nearby coffee shop twice a week; otherwise commutes by tube or cycles when weather allows.
Checks in with their partner briefly before leaving for the day if schedules permit.
workday: Blocks deep work time in the morning and schedules meetings in the afternoon where possible.
Runs weekly stand-ups and a bi-weekly team retro; one-on-ones with direct reports every two weeks.
Lunch often eaten at desk while catching up with a podcast or walking to a local market for fresh ingredients.
Uses an hour in the late afternoon for admin tasks: timesheets, budgets, and stakeholder updates.
evening: Aims to finish formal work by 7:00 PM on most days, though occasional late calls for client time zones occur.
Cook dinner with partner or meet friends for a neighbourhood restaurant twice a week.
Spends an hour on a personal project, reading or planning for travel.
Prepares a short priorities list for the next day before bed.
weekend: Longer bike rides or day-trips to nearby towns, food markets and secondhand bookshops.
Dedicated 2–3 hour block for hobby projects (photography editing, tinkering with a small hydroponic balcony setup).
Occasionally offers pro-bono mentoring sessions or volunteers at a community digital literacy session.
Enjoys a proper lie-in once a week and a slow, leisurely brunch.

physical.general_state: Good overall. Regularly active, cycles and walks. Keeps a mostly plant-forward diet with occasional meat.
physical.height_weight: Average build, maintains weight through regular activity and mindful eating.
physical.allergies: Mild hay fever in spring; seasonal antihistamines when pollen counts are high.
physical.past_injuries: Minor ankle sprain in late twenties from cycling; recovered fully.
physical.sleep: Usually 7 hours per night when routines are consistent; poorer sleep during high-stress project phases.
physical.substance_use: Occasional alcohol socially (1-3 drinks/week on average). Coffee daily in moderation.

mental.general_state: Generally resilient but susceptible to burnout if work-life boundaries erode for prolonged periods.
mental.past_mental_health: Experienced a period of heightened anxiety in their mid-twenties during a high-pressure job; learned coping strategies through cognitive-behavioral techniques and short-course therapy.
mental.current_practices: Mindfulness breathing, occasional therapy check-ins during busy seasons, active social support network, structured time-off policy adherence.
mental.access_to_care: Has private health coverage through employer for counselling and physical health checkups.

relationships.name: Aisha Patel
relationships.description: Aisha works in urban planning; pragmatic and supportive. They share cooking duties, travel planning and occasional work-life boundary negotiations. Relationship is long-term and stabilising; they coordinate calendars to protect weekends.

relationships.name: Karen Reid
relationships.description: Lives in a suburban town two hours away. Retired schoolteacher. Close relationship; Karen is emotionally supportive and enjoys hearing about Tamsin's work and travels.

relationships.name: Mark Reid
relationships.description: Semi-retired IT technician. Practical, mildly sceptical of corporate buzzwords, but proud of Tamsin's achievements.

relationships.name: Elliot Reid
relationships.description: Works in hospitality, friendly but lives in a different city. They video-call irregularly and catch up on family events.

relationships.name: Lina Gómez
relationships.relation: Close friend and former university roommate
relationships.description: Works in public health research. Regular sounding board for career decisions and shares a passion for city exploration and coffee.

relationships.name: Professional network
relationships.description: A wide network of contacts in healthcare IT and consulting, used for recruitment, reference checks and occasional collaboration on bids.

other_facts: Grew up in a mid-sized coastal town; childhood included visits to tidepools and a first job at a small bookshop during school holidays.
Chose Computer Science at university because of a fascination with how small code changes can change user experience.
Lived in Edinburgh for undergraduate studies and learned to appreciate long walks and the festival atmosphere.
Moved to Manchester for the master's degree where they developed an interest in management, operations and public systems.
First job was as a junior business analyst at a software house, where they discovered an aptitude for stakeholder facilitation.
Had a defining early-career project that failed to meet expectations due to scope creep; the experience shaped their rigorous approach to scoping and governance.
Is proud of having led a three-hospital go-live with minimal patient-facing disruption after a year of detailed planning.
Speaks intermediate Spanish: able to navigate travel conversations and read local press with some help.
Has a small balcony garden with herbs, a dwarf lemon tree and a portable hydroponic planter that they tinker with on weekends.
Keeps a small collection of well-worn notebooks going back ten years; uses them to track professional growth and lessons learned.
Prefers analogue note-taking for brainstorming, then transcribes key points into Notion.
Has a scar on their left forearm from a kitchen accident cutting vegetables at age 19; funny story in family gatherings.
Volunteered for a local charity teaching basic computer skills to older adults for three years.
Once backpacked through Portugal and remained fond of Portuguese pastries and small coastal towns.
Has a habit of buying postcards from every city they visit and sometimes forgets to send them.
Was a team captain for a university project that won a small national student prize for a prototype healthcare app.
Has a favourite local bakery where staff know their order: pain au chocolat and black coffee.
Is mildly obsessed with good stationery: prefers fountain pens for journaling and a specific brand of dot-grid notebook.
Keeps a modest emergency fund and contributes monthly to a retirement plan; financially cautious but willing to invest in career development.
Learnt to skateboard in their mid-twenties as a challenge with a friend and still enjoys occasional practice in a park.
Has a close mentor in the consultancy sector who provides quarterly career advice and informal references.
Enjoys organising small dinner parties and is known among friends for a reliable roast dinner recipe.
Has experienced and recovered from job-related imposter syndrome episodes; counters them with written lists of accomplishments.
Wrote an internal playbook for post-go-live stabilisation now used by two teams in their organisation.
Suffered a brief period of professional burnout in their late twenties and now treats annual leave as sacred time.
Is very particular about backups: multiple local and cloud backups for personal photos and critical documents.
Has a quirky travel superstition: buys a small charm in every new country they visit and keeps them in a bowl.
Was once interviewed on a niche podcast about digital transformation in the NHS; keeps a link in their portfolio.
Has donated blood regularly until a temporary deferral after travel; plans to resume donations when eligible.
Owns a reliable secondhand bicycle bought from a local cooperative and maintains it at community workshops.
Has a small collection of vinyl records from weekend market finds and plays them on a basic but well-loved turntable.
Keeps a folder of 'things that went well' to read during stressful patches; includes thank-you emails and small wins.
Is mildly competitive in board games and enjoys being the one to suggest the next strategic move at game night.
Was part of a small organising committee for a regional tech meetup, which taught them event logistics and sponsor relations.
Believes in practical sustainability: fixes items where possible and uses local repair cafes.
Has a favourite annual ritual: a short winter getaway to a coastal town with Aisha to recharge and plan the coming year.
Keeps a list of micro-habits to improve focus (e.g., 10-minute morning planning, 5-minute evening reflection) and experiments with them quarterly.
You regularly donate to environmental and social justice organizations.
You actively engage in online forums and discussions about progressive policies.
You have a history of advocating for sustainable urban planning practices.
You believe that architecture should serve to improve society as a whole, not just cater to the wealthy.
Has a deep respect for historical figures known for their leadership and decisiveness.
Collects memorabilia or objects related to hierarchy and authority (e.g., medals, antique military paraphernalia).
Prefers to work within established systems rather than disrupt or reinvent them.
Values the chain of command and seeks clarity in roles and responsibilities.
